March 10, 1950
Mr. L. J. A. van Dijk
Programme Specialist
Dept, of Mass Comounication
UNESCO
19, Avenue Kleber
Paris 16, France
Dear Mr. van Dijk;
Your letter to Dr. Skorala reached me the day after 1
had answered your letter to me concerning our work at Iowa.
I have some additional information, however, which might be
helpful.
One of the most helpful sources should be a pamphlet
called Credit Courses &£ Television published by the American
Council on Education, This is a report of a conference which
was held on this subject in February, 1955. It can be obtained
by writing to Mrs. Dorothy Smith, American Council on Education,
17S5 Massachusetts Avenue, Washington 6, D. C. Mrs. Smith
would also have other general information on the schools tele*
casting courses for credit.
The American Association of Colleges for Teacher Educa-
tlon has compiled some information on this subject. The
association bulletin of April 11, 1957, for example, included
a list of teachers colleges which offered telecourses for
credit. The president of this association is Donald P. Cottrell,
Dean, College of Education, Ohio State University, Columbus,
Ohio.
The department of continuing education at Michigan State
University, East Lansing, Michigan has done a number of
yearly surveys of the institutions offering television courses
for credit. The reports have Included course names, number
of credits, and cost. These should be useful to you.
The correspondence study division of the National
University Extension Association has begun worrying about
this matter of using television in connection with corres¬
pondence courses. Up to this point, however, 1 do not believe
that they have done much about it except talk. One group with¬
